curriculum_alignment.nerdc_description: First Republic, Civil War, military rule, democratization, contemporary issues

learning_objectives: Describe the First Republic structure and early political tensions
Explain causes and consequences of the Nigerian Civil War (1967–1970)
Outline phases of military rule and key policies
Trace the return to democracy in 1999 and subsequent developments
Discuss contemporary governance and development challenges
prerequisites: Understanding of federal structure and regions

content_sections.title: First Republic (1960–1966)
content_sections.content: Parliamentary system: President (ceremonial) + Prime Minister (executive). Major parties: NPC (north), NCNC (east), Action Group (west). Issues: census controversies, election disputes, regional tensions, January 1966 coup.

content_sections.title: Civil War (1967–1970)
content_sections.content: Causes: ethnic/regional mistrust post-coups, pogroms, failure of Aburi Accord, declaration of Republic of Biafra (May 1967). War phases: initial secession, federal counteroffensive, blockades. Consequences: casualties, displacement, economic disruption; post-war policy of 'No Victor, No Vanquished', reconciliation, 3Rs (Reconstruction, Rehabilitation, Reconciliation).

content_sections.title: Military Rule and Transitions
content_sections.content: Key regimes: Gowon (1966–75) post-war reconstruction; Murtala/Obasanjo (1975–79) reforms and 1979 handover; Buhari (1983–85) anti-corruption/War Against Indiscipline; Babangida (1985–93) SAP, annulled June 12 election; Abacha (1993–98) authoritarian rule; Abdulsalami (1998–99) transition.

content_sections.title: Return to Democracy and Contemporary Issues
content_sections.content: 1999 Fourth Republic: Constitution (presidential system); elected President Obasanjo (1999). Subsequent elections (2003, 2007, 2011, 2015 power alternation, 2019, 2023). Issues: governance, corruption, security (insurgency, banditry), economic diversification, federal character principle, devolution debates.

worked_examples.title: Identifying a Cause of the Civil War
worked_examples.context: Failure of the Aburi Accord led to mistrust.
worked_examples.problem: How did this contribute to the conflict?
worked_examples.solution: The breakdown of agreed power-sharing/restructuring increased distrust between federal and eastern leaders, prompting secession declaration and escalation to war.

worked_examples.title: Policy Under Military Rule
worked_examples.problem: What was one goal and one criticism of SAP?
worked_examples.solution: Goal: liberalize economy, reduce state spending, encourage private sector. Criticism: led to hardship via devaluation, subsidy removal, social unrest.

worked_examples.title: Democratic Transition
worked_examples.problem: Name one factor that made the transition possible.
worked_examples.solution: Abdulsalami Abubakar's short transition program, constitution drafting, elections; domestic/international pressure for civilian rule; fatigue with military governance.

practice_problems.problem: Name the ceremonial head in the First Republic.
State one cause of the Civil War.
practice_problems.answer: Regional/ethnic tensions after coups; pogroms; failed Aburi Accord; secession move (any one).

practice_problems.problem: Name one military ruler between 1983 and 1999.
Give one principle of the 1999 Constitution.
practice_problems.answer: Presidential system; federal character; separation of powers; fundamental rights (any one).

practice_problems.problem: Explain 'No Victor, No Vanquished' policy aim.
practice_problems.answer: Promote reconciliation after Civil War, avoid punitive measures, reintegrate Biafra region, focus on 3Rs (Reconstruction, Rehabilitation, Reconciliation).

practice_problems.problem: How did June 12, 1993 annulment affect trust in government?
practice_problems.answer: Undermined legitimacy, sparked protests/strikes, deepened public distrust, pressured regime toward transition.

practice_problems.problem: Name one contemporary governance challenge and a policy response.
practice_problems.answer: Security (insurgency/banditry) → military plus community policing; corruption → anti-graft agencies; economic diversification → support agriculture/tech/SMEs.

practice_problems.problem: If population grows 2.5% yearly, approximate doubling time?

exam_style_questions.question: Analyze two causes and two consequences of the Nigerian Civil War, and explain how the 3Rs policy addressed the aftermath.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Causes: coups/ethnic tension, Aburi failure, secession. Consequences: casualties, displacement, economic disruption. 3Rs aimed at healing and rebuilding.

exam_style_questions.question: Discuss one military regime (1983–1999) and its major policies, then evaluate one positive and one negative impact.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Choose Buhari/Babangida/Abacha; outline aims (anti-corruption, SAP, stability) and impacts (discipline vs hardship; growth vs repression).
